conclusion: Determine if the two objects have the same velocity at time t1 by analyzing accelerations and velocities over time.
Object A has a constant acceleration a_A; Object B has an acceleration that starts at zero and increases linearly with time according to a_B = kt.
Velocity v(t) can be found by integrating the acceleration a(t).
For Object A, v_A(t) = a_A t since it starts from rest.
For Object B, v_B(t) = (kt^2)/2 since it starts from rest.
At time t1, v_A(t1) = a_A t1 and v_B(t1) = (k t1^2)/2.
t2 = 2t1; at t2, velocities of both objects must be equal due to equal total displacements.
At t2, v_A(t2) = a_A (2t1) and v_B(t2) = 2k t1^2.
Equating v_A(t2) and v_B(t2), solve for k: k = a_A.
Substitute k = a_A into velocity equations at t1: v_A(t1) = a_A t1 and v_B(t1) = (a_A^2 t1^2)/4.
Compare v_A(t1) = a_A t1 and v_B(t1) = (a_A t1)/2; conclude v_A(t1) â‰  v_B(t1).
Final answer: No, the two objects do not have the same velocity at time t1.
